Process safety information, operating procedures, safety work practices, and other facility operations must be reviewed, evaluated, and updated if the change covered by MoC results in a change to those areas. 3.7  Pre-startup Reviews

Evraz Stratcor's Management of Change Equipment Release program also requires that a safety review be performed before any change or modification to a process. This safety review confirms that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate; and training of each employee involved in operating a process is complete. 

3.8  Compliance Audit

Compliance with PSM standards will be evaluated at least every three years through a documented audit to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the PSM standard are adequate and being followed.  Deficiencies noted during the audit will be annotated and reported to management.  Progress toward resolving deficiencies will be tracked after a ranking and prioritization of items requiring response.  Documentation that deficiencies have been corrected will be maintained with the audit. The two most recent compliance audit reports will be retained by the Environmental Manager or plant management.  

3.9  Incident

1.0  Accidental Release Prevention And Response Policies
	
At Evraz Stratcor, Inc. (Evraz Stratcor), we use anhydrous ammonia (AA) as a reactant in the recovery of vanadium products and chlorine (Cl2) and titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) in the halide manufacturing process. AA, Cl2, and TiCl4 are regulated substances under the Accidental Release Program regulations, which governs the Risk Management Plan (RMP).  Certain safety precautions must be observed when handling these chemicals to prevent unnecessary human exposure and to reduce the threat to employees and nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, training of our personnel who operate the processes, and the safety devices inherent in the design of their storage vessels. 

Our emergency response program presents a logical coordinated course of action to be followed in case of an emergency.  The program utilizes information from the Emergency Response Guidebook by the Department of Transportation.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.

2.0  Evraz Stratcor, Inc. and Regulated Substances

Our Hot Springs facility includes a vanadium recovery process and a halides manufacturing process. AA is used to aid in the recovery of the vanadium product in a crystallization circuit. Cl2 is introduced into the vanadium halide production process as a reactant. TiCI4 is blended with vanadium oxytrichloride to form vanadium-titanium mixtures.  AA, Cl2, and TiCI4 are the only chemicals that EPA has identified on the RMP Rule Toxic Substances list and that are stored above threshold quantities. Evraz Stratcor has no flammable substances regulated by Part 68.  Storage conditions for the toxic chemicals regulated under the RMP Rule by Part 68 are provided in the following

3.0  Accidental Release Prevention Program
	
As part of our general prevention program, we have integrated chemical-specific prevention steps that help minimize the possibility of any leak of a hazardous substance that poses a potential danger both onsite and/or offsite.  Evraz Stratcor's PSM program follows the requirements of the OSHA standards (29 CFR 1910.119) that are given in Part 68. Although the PSM program has been developed to follow the guidelines of the OSHA PSM standard, it should be noted that the Evraz Stratcor facility is under the jurisdiction of the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA).The requirements for our prevention program take a proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of regulated substances that pose a danger to human health and the environment. This prevention program is a vital part of our everyday operations as safety is our chief priority. Our program employs high standards and includes the following steps and programs that lead to successful accident prevention: 

3.1  Process Safety Information

Process safety includes information pertaining to the hazards of the substances in the process, information pertaining to the technology of the process, and information pertaining to the equipment in the process. This information, updated regularly, helps to educate all employees on the current status of covered processes. The chemical hazards of the process chemicals used at the Evraz Stratcor facility are covered by the Material Safet

y Data Sheets (MSDS) and the Hazard Communication (HAZCOM) program required by MSHA in 30 CFR Part 47.   

Information pertaining to the technology of the process and the equipment in the process is compiled in the PSM program. 

3.2  Process Hazard Analysis

Evraz Stratcor's current PSM program includes Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations for its covered substances that follow HAZOP methodologies. Recommendations resulting from the PHA are promptly addressed following the completion of the review. The resolutions to the recommendations are performed and documented as soon as possible and a schedule of the completion of all resolutions to recommendations resulting from the PHA is developed and kept on-file in the PSM program with the PHA. 

3.3  Operating Procedures

The PSM program has developed and documented procedures for each operating phase of Evraz Stratcor's processes covered by the PSM program. Standard operating procedures (SOPs) for each department are kept on the server for electronic access. SOPs are also readily accessible to employees. The SOPs are revised as needed as part of their ongoing review and reflect the most current operating practices of the covered processes. Included in the SOPs are practices for such operations as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, hot work permits, and safe work permits. The SOPs address elements for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. 

3.4  Training

Operating and maintenance personnel at Evraz Stratcor, as well as any contract employees, as required by the regulation, must be trained in an overview of the process and in the developed operating procedures. This training must empha specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  

Initial training must occur before an employee's assignment to a PSM covered process. The Los

s Control Program and Employee Training Program outline the procedures for achieving this goal and it is the responsibility of the Area Supervisor/Superintendent to document that employees complete the required training.  

Refresher training will be completed at least every three years or more often if plant management determines through consultation with operation personnel a different frequency is required. Training will be documented and kept on file by management. Training documentation indicates whether the employee received and understood the training required by the regulation.

3.5  Mechanical Integrity

The General Manager is responsible for implementation and adherence to the mechanical integrity program by Evraz Stratcor facility personnel and contractors.  The mechanical integrity program for the Evraz Stratcor facility is maintained and implemented by the Maintenance and Engineering Department. Evraz Stratcor personnel completing inspection, maintenance, and preventive maintenance includes plant technicians, maintenance, and engineering personnel. A level of knowledge of mechanical and electrical equipment, process hazards, and safe work practices is required within the job description and within other elements of the PSM program.

Inspection and testing will be documented as described in the mechanical integrity program maintained by the Maintenance and Engineering Department.  Equipment deficiencies found during routine operation, maintenance activities, or tests/inspections will be addressed before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation.

The program coincides with our Quality Assurance program and an important element of quality assurance is the consistent use of the Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review.  
	
 

3.6	Management of Change

The Management of Change (MoC) procedures must address any change other than "replacement in kind" made in or to a PSM covere

Investigation

An accident investigation team investigates any accident on-site that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a release of a regulated substance covered by the PSM program. The Incident Investigation Team consists of the Safety Manager, Area Supervisor/Superintendent, Environmental Manager, and/or the President of Evraz Stratcor/General Manager with additional personnel augmenting the team as necessary according to the location and circumstances of the incident or near miss.  This team will be required to conduct interviews of witnesses, gather needed documentation, and complete a final report.  The investigation must be initiated within 48 hours of incidents or near misses.

The information gathered, recommendations made, and corrective actions required during the investigation will be documented within the Accident/Incident Investigation Report and kept on file in the Safety Office.   Information within the Accident/Incident Investigation Report will be retained for at least five years. Personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the investigation findings, including applicable contract employees, shall review the Accident/Incident Investigation Report.

3.10  Employee Participation

It is the policy of Evraz Stratcor to encourage employee participation in all facets of plant operation. Our program allows for constant input from operators in such items as process safety information, process hazards analyses, training, and management of change. 

3.11  Hot Work Permits

Evraz Stratcor maintains specific procedures for obtaining a permit to perform maintenance including hot work in any area that could possibly affect a process involving a PSM covered processes. 

3.12  Contractors

Evraz Stratcor maintains strict standards for contractors and their employees who perform any process-related work on-site. Applicable contractors must be evaluated and approved prior to their being allowed to work at the Evraz Stratcor facility.  C

onfirmation of the approved contractor's receipt and understanding of the Contractor Safety Requirements will be documented and maintained on file at the facility. Approved contractors are responsible for their contract employees being properly trained or instructed to perform work in compliance with the Evraz Stratcor safety, health, and environmental standards.

4.0  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

4.1  Anhydrous Ammonia

Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  These controls include vents, relief valves, check valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, alarms, and excess flow devices.  
4.2  Chlorine

Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental release of chlorine.  These controls include a chlorine monitoring system, vents, relief valves and check valves, rupture disks, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, scrubbers, emergency air supply, grounding equipment, excess flow devices, and fuse plugs.  

4.3  Titanium Tetrachloride

Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental release of titanium tetrachloride.  These controls include fusible plugs, interlocks, manual and automatic shut-offs, excess flow devices, purge system, designated storage areas, and limited quantities.  

5.0  Five Year Accident History

5.1  Anhydrous Ammonia

During the past five years, Evraz Stratcor has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, resulting in on-site or off-site site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

5.2 Chlorine

During the past five years, Evraz Stratcor has not had an accidental chlorine release, resulting in on-site or off-site site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

hloride

During the past five years, Evraz Stratcor has not had an accidental titanium tetrachloride release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

6.0  Emergency Response Programs

Emergency planning and response procedures are documented in Evraz Stratcor's "Emergency Procedures Handbook". A copy of the document is available electronically on the company server. This plan will be updated as necessary when modifications are made to the facility.

Stractcor's Emergency Procedures Handbook provides information regarding the actions to be taken by employees in the event of an emergency, describes evacuation procedures, and procedures for handling releases, including small releases (e.g., use of B-Kit for chlorine leak). Evraz Stratcor's Safety and Health Department is responsible for briefing employees once every year on the contents of the Emergency Procedures Handbook. A Security Committee is assigned to provide guidance and to carry out the procedures outlined in the Emergency Procedures Handbook
The emergency response plan developed has been coordinated with the Garland County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and local emergency responders.  In addition, Evraz Stratcor is included in the Garland County Hazardous Material Emergency Operations Plan.

7.0  Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Evraz Stratcor conducts Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) at least every 5 years to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of highly hazardous chemicals. The PHAs provide information to assist Evraz Stratcor in improving safety and reducing the consequences of releases of hazardous chemicals.  Information provided by the PHAs is used to analyze potential causes and consequences of fires, explosions, releases of toxic or flammable chemicals, and major spills of hazardous

chemicals. 

PHAs, utilizing the HAZOP analysis methodology, have been completed for the following processes at the Evraz Stratcor facility:

¿	Vanadium Halides and Solutions Project PHA (August 2010)
¿	Modified Vanadium Oxide PHA (April 2011)
¿	Solvent Extraction Circuit PHA (August 2011)

Upon completion of the PHAs (initial and updates), a report of findings (or punch list) is developed and action items are ranked in order of greatest risk.  Items with the greatest risk will be attended to first. However, if easy, quick, inexpensive, or procedural fixes can be accomplished without taking resources away from the high risk items, those easy fixes are completed and, with proper documentation, removed from the list.  Documentation of this punch list, progress toward completion of those items, and PHA documentation are maintained in the Safety Office. Currently, Evraz Stratcor, Inc. utilizes an electronic work order system to schedule and track completion of each item.  The maintenance supervisor is responsible for making sure each item is completed and checked off.
